did.abstract: Two letters from D. Ditmars to his brother John Ditmars in Jamaica, New York, from the colony of Exxequebo (Essequibo), British Guyana, dated 1802 and 1815. The Ditmars (also spelled Ditmas) were a prominent family who owned property in Kings County and Queens County, New York, from the 17th century onward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters from D. Ditmars to his brother John Ditmars in Jamaica, New York, from the colony of Exxequebo (Essequibo), British Guyana, dated 1802. In one letter he expresses his pleasure at hearing news from friends and family back home, describes the colony where he is staying, and describes a number of local birds he has observed in the area. In the second letter D. Ditmars explains that he has closed his business and will depart for America the following month. This collection also includes a receipt.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: The Ditmars (also spelled Ditmas) were a prominent family who owned property in Kings County and Queens County, New York, from the 17th century onward.
